did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, University of Virginia Library
did.unittitle:
John Peter Jones Civil War Notebook
1862-1863
did.abstract: Jones's notebook contains signed entries for ca. 269 fellow Confederate prisoners, many of whom were captured at the Battle of Gettysburg. Each officer recorded his name, home town, regiment, and date and place of capture.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
See the
University of Virginia Library’s use policy.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: John Peter Jones Civil War Notebook, 1862-1863, Accession #11095, Special Collections Dept., University of Virginia Library, Charlottesville, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: This volume was given to the Library by Mary Roy Dawson Edwards (Mrs. Charles R. Edwards) of Schuyler, Virginia, on April 27, 1993.

altformavail.head: Alternative Form
altformavail.p: This entire volume is also available on microfilm as Manuscripts Division Reel #2337.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: John Peter Jones enlisted on July 8, 1861 in Buckingham County, Virginia, and was wounded at the battle of Gaines Mills (June 27, 1862) but after recuperating in a Richmond hospital returned to duty. He was captured at the battle of Gettysburg (July 3, 1863) in the aftermath of Pickett's charge and confined at Fort McHenry, Maryland, Fort Delaware (on Pea Patch Island in the Delaware River), and Johnson's Island until exchanged and paroled at Point Lookout, Maryland on March 14, 1865. After the war he joined John Bowie Strange Camp, United Confederate Veterans, in Albemarle County, Virginia; he died in 1910 and was buried in Oakwood Cemetery, Charlottesville. 1

Johnson's Island, Sandusky Bay, Lake Erie, was a 300-acre Union military prison where Confederate officers (3,000) and enlisted men and disloyal civilians were held in barracks. The prison itself consisted of a four-sided stockade surrounded by a fifteen-foot high wooden fence whose base a ditch surrounded to prevent tunneling. The first 200 prisoners arrived in April 1862; after July 1862 mostly Confederate officers were housed on the island. By the end of the war approximately 15,000 men had been confined there.

1William A. Young, Jr. and Patricia C. Young, 56th Virginia Infantry(Lynchburg, Virginia: H. E. Howard, Inc., 1990), 154; Homer Richey, Memorial History of the John Bowie Strange Camp, United Confederate Veterans, Including Some Account of Others Who Served in the Confederate Armies from Albemarle County, Together with Brief Sketches of the Albemarle Chapter of the United Daughters of the Confederacy and the R.T.W. Duke Camp, Sons of Confederate Veterans(Charlottesville, Va., Press of the Michie Company, 1920), 58.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: This is a prison notebook maintained by Confederate Captain John Peter Jones (1838-1910), Company, D, 56th Virginia Infantry Regiment, contains the signatures of ca. 269 Confederate officers captured between February 1863 and August 1864 and held at Johnson's Island, Sandusky, Ohio.

Jones's notebook contains signed entries of fellow Confederate prisoners, many of whom were captured during 1863 battles, campaigns and engagements including Gettysburg; Falling Waters (Maryland and Virginia); Port Hudson, Louisiana; Rappahannock Bridge/Station, Virginia; Bristoe Station, Virginia, and, Cumberland Gap and Shelbyville, Tennessee. Each officer recorded his name, home address, regiment, and date and place of capture. Most were lieutenants with regiments from North Carolina and Virginia the most heavily represented. Each page contains three entries excepting page 88 which only has two.

The highest ranking prisoner to sign this notebook was Major General Isaac Ridgeway Trimble (1802-1888), captured at Gettysburg, July 3, 1863, who signed and dated page 69 on January 31, 1864; the signature of one of Trimble's staff, Major William Carvel Hall, Assistant Adjutant General, also appears on page 69. The signatures of other Confederate generals include Brigadier General James J. Archer (1817-1864), page 70; Brigadier General John R. Jones (1827-1901), page 71; Brigadier General John Wesley Frazer (1827-1906), page 84; Missouri State Guard Brigadier General Meriwether "Jeff" Thompson (1826-1876), page 85, and, Brigadier General William N. R. Beall (1825-1883), page 87. Also present is the signature of Major Henry Kyd Douglas (1838-1903), page 86 (a staff officer of General Thomas J. "Stonewall" Jackson). Several other staff members also signed the volume. 1

1Bruce C. Allardice, More Generals in Gray(Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 1995); Mark M. Boatner, The Civil War Dictionary(New York: David McKay Company, 1959); Joseph H. Crute, Jr., Confederate Staff Officers, 1861-1865(Powhatan, Virginia: Derwent Books, 1982); Joseph H. Crute, Jr., Units of the Confederate States Army(Midlothian, Virginia: Derwent Books, 1987), E. B. Long, The Civil War Day By Day(Garden City, New York: Doubleday & Company, 1971), and, Ezra J. Warner, Generals in Gray: Lives of the Confederate Commanders(Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 1959.
